title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: Censo Demografico (Demographic Census) main source population denominators Brazil, essential calculating mortality rates, disease incidence, epidemiological indicators. healthbR package provides direct access Census population data via IBGE SIDRA API, covering:

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: censo_info(2022)

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: common use case: getting population state denominator health indicators.
code: # total population by state, Census 2022 pop_state <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state") pop_state

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: # population by sex, Brazil level pop_sex <- censo_populacao(   year = 2022,   variables = "sex",   territorial_level = "brazil" ) pop_sex

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: # population by age and sex pop_age_sex <- censo_populacao(   year = 2022,   variables = "age_sex",   territorial_level = "brazil" ) pop_age_sex

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: # population by race, 2022 pop_race <- censo_populacao(   year = 2022,   variables = "race",   territorial_level = "state" ) pop_race

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: years censuses, IBGE publishes annual population estimates serve denominators:
code: # population estimates 2015-2021 estimates <- censo_estimativa(   year = 2015:2021,   territorial_level = "state" ) estimates

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: typical epidemiological workflow combines mortality data (SIM) Census denominators:
code: # step 1: get population denominator pop_2010 <- censo_populacao(   year = 2010,   variables = "total",   territorial_level = "state" )  # step 2: suppose you have mortality data (from SIM or other source) # deaths_by_state <- sim_data(year = 2010) |> count(state)  # step 3: calculate crude mortality rate # mortality_rate <- deaths_by_state |> #   left_join(pop_2010, by = "state") |> #   mutate(rate_per_100k = (n / population) * 100000)

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: Census module includes catalog SIDRA tables organized theme:
code: # list all available tables censo_sidra_tables()  # filter by theme censo_sidra_tables(theme = "disability") censo_sidra_tables(theme = "indigenous")  # search by keyword censo_sidra_search("quilombola") censo_sidra_search("saneamento")

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
text: full flexibility, use censo_sidra_data() query Census table:
code: # population by race from table 9605 pop_race_raw <- censo_sidra_data(   table = 9605,   territorial_level = "state",   year = 2022,   variable = 93,   classifications = list("86" = "allxt") ) pop_race_raw

title: Population Denominators from the Census with healthbR
code: # compare population across census years pop_2010 <- censo_populacao(year = 2010, territorial_level = "brazil") pop_2022 <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "brazil")  # or use estimates for intercensitary years pop_series <- censo_estimativa(   year = 2001:2021,   territorial_level = "brazil" ) pop_series

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: healthbR package provides access four DATASUS information systems via FTP, covering mortality, live births, hospital admissions, outpatient production: four modules share infrastructure: DBC decompression: .dbc files (compressed DBF) decompressed internally using vendored C code – external dependencies required. FTP download: files fetched ftp.datasus.gov.br automatic retry exponential backoff. Cache: downloaded data cached locally Parquet (arrow installed) .rds format. Consistent API: every module exposes *_years(), *_info(), *_variables(), *_dictionary(), *_data(), *_cache_status(), *_clear_cache().

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: module provides set helper functions. quick tour using SIM example: pattern works sinasc_*(), sih_*(), sia_*().
code: # available years sim_years() #> [1] 1996 1997 1998 ... 2023  # module information (data source, key variables, usage tips) sim_info()  # list all variables with descriptions sim_variables()  # search for a specific variable sim_variables(search = "causa")  # data dictionary with category labels sim_dictionary("SEXO")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: SIM (Sistema de Informacoes sobre Mortalidade) contains individual death records based Declaracao de Obito ().

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: # all deaths in Acre, 2022 obitos_ac <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC") obitos_ac

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: cause parameter filters underlying cause death (CAUSABAS) using CID-10 prefix matching:
code: # deaths from acute myocardial infarction (I21) obitos_iam <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cause = "I21")  # all cardiovascular deaths (chapter I) obitos_cardio <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cause = "I")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: obitos_ac <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  obitos_ac |>   mutate(chapter = substr(CAUSABAS, 1, 1)) |>   count(chapter, sort = TRUE)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: SINASC (Sistema de Informacoes sobre Nascidos Vivos) contains individual live birth records Declaracao de Nascido Vivo (DN).

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: nasc_ac <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC") nasc_ac

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: anomaly parameter filters CODANOMAL variable using CID-10 prefix matching:
code: # births with any congenital anomaly (chapter Q) anomalias <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", anomaly = "Q")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: nasc_ac <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  nasc_ac |>   mutate(peso_num = as.numeric(PESO)) |>   filter(!is.na(peso_num), peso_num > 0) |>   mutate(weight_group = case_when(     peso_num < 1500 ~ "Very low (<1500g)",     peso_num < 2500 ~ "Low (1500-2499g)",     peso_num < 4000 ~ "Normal (2500-3999g)",     TRUE            ~ "High (>=4000g)"   )) |>   count(weight_group)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: SIH (Sistema de Informacoes Hospitalares) contains individual hospital admission records AIH (Autorizacao de Internacao Hospitalar). Unlike SIM SINASC, data organized monthly.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: # admissions in Acre, January 2022 intern_jan <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC") intern_jan

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: SIH data monthly – one file per UF per month. Use month control months download:
code: # single month sih_data(year = 2022, month = 6, uf = "AC")  # first semester sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1:6, uf = "AC")  # all 12 months (default when month = NULL -- downloads 12 files per UF) sih_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: diagnosis parameter filters principal diagnosis (DIAG_PRINC) using CID-10 prefix matching:
code: # respiratory admissions (chapter J) resp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  # pneumonia specifically (J12-J18) pneum <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC",                   diagnosis = c("J12", "J13", "J14", "J15", "J16", "J17", "J18"))

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: intern <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  intern |>   mutate(chapter = substr(DIAG_PRINC, 1, 1)) |>   count(chapter, sort = TRUE)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: SIA (Sistema de Informacoes Ambulatoriais) contains outpatient production records. Like SIH, data monthly, SIA also 13 file types covering different categories outpatient care.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: # outpatient production in Acre, January 2022 (default type = "PA") ambul_jan <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC") ambul_jan  # different file type: high-cost medications med <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "AM")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: # filter by SIGTAP procedure code (prefix match on PA_PROC_ID) consult <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", procedure = "0301")  # filter by CID-10 diagnosis (prefix match on PA_CIDPRI) resp <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
code: ambul <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  ambul |>   mutate(proc_group = substr(PA_PROC_ID, 1, 2)) |>   count(proc_group, sort = TRUE)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: key strength healthbR ability combine data different DATASUS modules Census denominators single workflow. three practical examples.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: Calculate crude cardiovascular mortality rate per 100,000 population:
code: # step 1: count cardiovascular deaths in Sao Paulo, 2022 obitos_cardio <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "SP", cause = "I") n_obitos <- nrow(obitos_cardio)  # step 2: get population denominator from Census 2022 pop_sp <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state") |>   filter(grepl("Paulo", territorial_unit))  # step 3: calculate rate taxa_mortalidade <- n_obitos / pop_sp$population * 100000 taxa_mortalidade

what: Live births to deaths ratio (SINASC + SIM)
title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: Compare number live births deaths state:
code: # births and deaths in Acre, 2022 nascimentos <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC") obitos <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  razao <- nrow(nascimentos) / nrow(obitos) razao #> ratio > 1 means more births than deaths (population growth)

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: Compare volumes costs respiratory care (CID-10 chapter J) hospital outpatient settings:
code: # hospital admissions for respiratory diseases, January 2022 intern_resp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  # outpatient production for respiratory diseases, January 2022 ambul_resp <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  # compare volumes n_internacoes <- nrow(intern_resp) n_ambulatorial <- nrow(ambul_resp)  # compare costs custo_intern <- sum(as.numeric(intern_resp$VAL_TOT), na.rm = TRUE) custo_ambul <- sum(as.numeric(ambul_resp$PA_VALAPR), na.rm = TRUE)  tibble::tibble(   setting = c("Hospital (SIH)", "Outpatient (SIA)"),   records = c(n_internacoes, n_ambulatorial),   total_cost_brl = c(custo_intern, custo_ambul) )

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: DATASUS modules cache downloaded data automatically. arrow package installed, data saved Parquet format (fast compact); otherwise, .rds used fallback.
code: # install arrow for optimized caching (recommended) install.packages("arrow")

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: module provides *_cache_status() *_clear_cache():
code: # check what is cached sim_cache_status() sih_cache_status() sia_cache_status()  # clear cache for a specific module sim_clear_cache()

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: Use uf download states need instead 27. Use month (SIH SIA) limit monthly downloads. Downloading full year states requires 324 files per module (27 UFs x 12 months). Use vars keep variables need, reducing memory usage. SIM SINASC annual (one file per UF per year), full-year download 27 files. SIH SIA monthly, full-year download 324 files per type. SIA 13 file types, downloading everything one year 4,212 files – always filter type, uf, month.

title: DATASUS Modules: SIM, SINASC, SIH, and SIA
text: DATASUS TabNet – online tabulation tool DATASUS data DATASUS FTP – public FTP server raw data files CID-10 (ICD-10) – International Classification Diseases, 10th revision SIGTAP – procedure code table SUS (SIA/SIH)

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: healthbR provides easy access Brazilian public health data directly R. package downloads, caches, processes data official sources (Ministry Health, IBGE, DATASUS), returning clean, analysis-ready tibbles following tidyverse conventions. package currently supports 9 data sources organized two groups: Surveys (IBGE / Ministry Health) DATASUS (Ministry Health FTP)

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: see available data sources glance: modules follow consistent API pattern: *_years() / *_info() – metadata available years *_variables() / *_dictionary() – variable names category labels *_data() – download load data *_cache_status() / *_clear_cache() – cache management
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr) list_sources() #> # A tibble: 11 x 5 #>    source  name                         description                    years       status #>    <chr>   <chr>                        <chr>                          <chr>       <chr> #>  1 vigitel VIGITEL                      Telephone survey on chronic... 2006-2024   available #>  2 pns     PNS - Pesquisa Nacional ...  National health survey (IBGE) 2013, 2019  available #>  ...

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: VIGITEL telephone survey conducted annually 27 state capitals, monitoring risk protective factors chronic non-communicable diseases. Key variables include pesorake (survey weight), diab (diabetes), hart (hypertension), fumante (smoker), imc (BMI).
code: # check available years vigitel_years()  # download data for a single year df <- vigitel_data(year = 2024)  # explore the data dictionary dict <- vigitel_dictionary()  # list variables vigitel_variables() # weighted prevalence of diabetes by city using srvyr library(srvyr)  df |>   as_survey_design(weights = pesorake) |>   group_by(cidade) |>   summarize(     prevalence = survey_mean(diab == 1, na.rm = TRUE),     n = unweighted(n())   )

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: PNS provides comprehensive data health conditions, lifestyle, healthcare access ~100,000 households.
code: # microdata pns <- pns_data(year = 2019)  # explore modules and variables pns_modules(year = 2019) pns_dictionary(year = 2019)  # tabulated indicators from SIDRA API (no download needed) pns_sidra_search("diabetes") pns_sidra_data(table = 4487, territorial_level = "state", year = 2019)

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: PNAD Continua includes health-related supplementary modules disability, housing conditions, primary health care (APS), household characteristics.
code: # list available modules pnadc_modules()  # download disability supplement defic <- pnadc_data(module = "deficiencia", year = 2019, quarter = 1)  # explore variables pnadc_variables(module = "deficiencia")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: POF (Household Budget Survey) contains data food insecurity (EBIA), individual food consumption, anthropometry, health expenses. See vignette("pof-health-data") detailed walkthrough.
code: # list available registers pof_registers(year = 2018)  # food consumption microdata consumo <- pof_data(year = 2018, register = "consumo_alimentar")  # food insecurity scale (EBIA) morador <- pof_data(year = 2018, register = "morador")  # variable dictionary for a specific register pof_dictionary(year = 2018, register = "morador")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: Census module queries IBGE SIDRA API population denominators, essential calculating mortality rates, incidence, epidemiological indicators. See vignette("censo-denominadores") epidemiological examples.
code: # population by state, sex, and age group (2022 Census) pop <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state")  # intercensitary population estimates (for years between censuses) est <- censo_estimativa(year = 2020, territorial_level = "state")  # query any Census SIDRA table directly censo_sidra_search("populacao") censo_sidra_data(table = 9514, territorial_level = "brazil", year = 2022)

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SIM contains individual death records death certificates (CID-10, 1996+).
code: # deaths in Acre, 2022 obitos <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # filter by cause of death (CID-10 prefix) obitos_cardio <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cause = "I")  # explore variables and categories sim_variables() sim_dictionary("CAUSABAS")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SINASC contains individual birth records including birth weight, gestational age, prenatal care, congenital anomalies.
code: # births in Acre, 2022 nascimentos <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # filter by congenital anomaly (CID-10 prefix) anomalias <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", anomaly = "Q")  sinasc_variables() sinasc_dictionary("PARTO")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SIH contains hospital admission records (AIH) diagnosis, procedures, length stay, costs. Data organized monthly.
code: # admissions in Acre, January 2022 internacoes <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # filter by principal diagnosis (CID-10 prefix) intern_resp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  sih_variables() sih_dictionary("DIAG_PRINC")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: SIA covers outpatient production data 13 file types (BPA, APAC, RAAS). See vignette("datasus-modules") cross-module analysis examples.
code: # outpatient production in Acre, January 2022 (default type: PA) ambulatorial <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # high-cost medications (APAC) medicamentos <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "AM")  # filter by procedure or diagnosis sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", procedure = "0301") sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "E11")

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: modules cache downloaded data automatically avoid repeated downloads. Install arrow optimized Parquet caching (recommended): Cache management works across modules:
code: install.packages("arrow") # check what is cached sim_cache_status() vigitel_cache_status()  # clear a module's cache sim_clear_cache()  # use a custom cache directory (e.g., for temporary use) sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cache_dir = tempdir())

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: healthbR’s real power comes combining data across modules. example, calculating mortality rates requires deaths (SIM) population (Censo):
code: library(dplyr)  # deaths by state deaths <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC") |>   count(name = "deaths")  # population by state pop <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state") |>   filter(nivel_territorial_codigo == "12")  # Acre  # crude mortality rate deaths$deaths / pop$valor * 100000

title: Introduction to healthbR
text: vignette("pof-health-data") – Analyzing food security nutrition POF vignette("censo-denominadores") – Population denominators epidemiology vignette("datasus-modules") – SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA depth Package website GitHub repository

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF (Pesquisa de Orçamentos Familiares) household budget survey conducted IBGE investigates household expenditures, living conditions, nutritional profiles Brazilian population. conducted partnership Ministry Health. healthbR package provides access POF microdata focus health-related data:

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: library(healthbR) library(dplyr)

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: Use pof_info() see health modules available edition:

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF edition contains multiple data registers. Use pof_registers() see :
code: # all registers pof_registers("2017-2018")  # only health-related registers pof_registers("2017-2018", health_only = TRUE)

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: downloading data, can browse available variables:
code: # list all variables in the domicilio register pof_variables("2017-2018", "domicilio")  # search for food security variables pof_variables("2017-2018", search = "ebia")  # search for weight-related variables pof_variables("2017-2018", "morador", search = "peso")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: EBIA (Escala Brasileira de Insegurança Alimentar) available 2017-2018 edition domicilio register. variable V6199 contains food security classification.

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: domicilio <- pof_data("2017-2018", "domicilio")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: EBIA classifies households four levels:

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: domicilio <- domicilio |>   mutate(     ebia = factor(       V6199,       levels = 1:4,       labels = c(         "Food security",         "Mild insecurity",         "Moderate insecurity",         "Severe insecurity"       )     )   )  # frequency table domicilio |>   count(ebia) |>   mutate(pct = n / sum(n) * 100)

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: proper population estimates, use survey design:
code: library(srvyr)  domicilio_svy <- pof_data("2017-2018", "domicilio", as_survey = TRUE)  # add EBIA categories domicilio_svy <- domicilio_svy |>   mutate(     ebia = factor(       V6199,       levels = 1:4,       labels = c(         "Food security",         "Mild insecurity",         "Moderate insecurity",         "Severe insecurity"       )     )   )  # weighted prevalence domicilio_svy |>   group_by(ebia) |>   summarize(     prevalence = survey_mean(na.rm = TRUE, vartype = "ci"),     n = unweighted(n())   )

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: # food insecurity by state domicilio_svy |>   group_by(UF, ebia) |>   summarize(     prevalence = survey_mean(na.rm = TRUE, vartype = "ci"),     n = unweighted(n())   ) |>   filter(ebia == "Severe insecurity") |>   arrange(desc(prevalence))

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: consumo_alimentar register contains detailed personal food intake data subsample. data available 2008-2009 2017-2018 editions.

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: consumo <- pof_data("2017-2018", "consumo_alimentar")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: # total daily caloric intake per person consumo |>   group_by(COD_UPA, NUM_DOM, NUM_UC, COD_INFORMANTE) |>   summarize(     total_kcal = sum(ENERGIA_KCAL, na.rm = TRUE),     total_protein = sum(PROTEINA, na.rm = TRUE),     total_carb = sum(CARBOIDRATO, na.rm = TRUE),     total_fat = sum(LIPIDIO, na.rm = TRUE),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   summarize(     mean_kcal = mean(total_kcal, na.rm = TRUE),     mean_protein = mean(total_protein, na.rm = TRUE),     mean_carb = mean(total_carb, na.rm = TRUE),     mean_fat = mean(total_fat, na.rm = TRUE)   )

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: despesa_individual register contains individual expenses, including health-related spending medications, health insurance, medical consultations.

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
code: despesas <- pof_data("2017-2018", "despesa_individual")

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: Health-related expenses can identified product group codes:
code: # explore expense categories despesas |>   count(QUADRO) |>   arrange(desc(n))

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: many analyses need combine data multiple registers. Use household identifier variables (COD_UPA, NUM_DOM, NUM_UC) merge:
code: # download morador (demographic data) and domicilio (household data) morador <- pof_data("2017-2018", "morador") domicilio <- pof_data("2017-2018", "domicilio")  # merge: add household-level EBIA to individual-level data morador_ebia <- morador |>   left_join(     domicilio |> select(COD_UPA, NUM_DOM, NUM_UC, V6199),     by = c("COD_UPA", "NUM_DOM", "NUM_UC")   ) |>   mutate(     ebia = factor(       V6199,       levels = 1:4,       labels = c(         "Food security",         "Mild insecurity",         "Moderate insecurity",         "Severe insecurity"       )     )   )  # food insecurity by age group morador_ebia |>   mutate(age_group = cut(V0403, breaks = c(0, 5, 12, 18, 30, 60, Inf))) |>   count(age_group, ebia) |>   group_by(age_group) |>   mutate(pct = n / sum(n) * 100)

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF conducted different years, data structure may vary. Use pof_info() check available edition:
code: # check health modules by edition pof_info("2017-2018")  # EBIA + food consumption pof_info("2008-2009")  # anthropometry + food consumption pof_info("2002-2003")  # expenses only

title: Analyzing Health Data from POF with healthbR
text: POF data files large. healthbR caches downloaded files locally download : arrow package installed, data cached Parquet format faster loading:
code: # check cached files pof_cache_status()  # clear cache if needed pof_clear_cache() # install arrow for optimized caching (recommended) install.packages("arrow")

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: healthbR provides easy access Brazilian public health data directly R. package downloads, caches, processes data official sources, returning clean, analysis-ready tibbles following tidyverse conventions.

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: DATASUS modules download .dbc files (compressed DBF) decompress internally using vendored C code – external dependencies required.

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: can install development version healthbR GitHub:
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("SidneyBissoli/healthbR")

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
code: library(healthbR)  # see all available data sources list_sources()

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
text: DATASUS modules follow consistent API: *_years(), *_info(), *_variables(), *_dictionary(), *_data(), *_cache_status(), *_clear_cache().
code: # mortality data -- deaths in Acre, 2022 obitos <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # filter by cause of death (CID-10 prefix) obitos_cardio <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC", cause = "I")  # live births in Acre, 2022 nascimentos <- sinasc_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # hospital admissions in Acre, January 2022 internacoes <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # filter by diagnosis (CID-10 prefix) intern_resp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", diagnosis = "J")  # outpatient production in Acre, January 2022 ambulatorial <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # different file type (e.g., high-cost medications) medicamentos <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "AM")

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
code: # VIGITEL telephone survey vigitel <- vigitel_data(year = 2024)  # PNS national health survey pns <- pns_data(year = 2019)  # PNAD Continua pnadc <- pnadc_data(year = 2023, quarter = 1)  # POF household budget survey pof <- pof_data(year = 2018, register = "morador")  # Census population pop <- censo_populacao(year = 2022, territorial_level = "state")

title: Access Brazilian Public Health Data
code: # list variables for any module sim_variables() sia_variables(search = "sexo")  # data dictionary with category labels sim_dictionary("SEXO") sia_dictionary("PA_RACACOR")

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: Retrieves population data Brazilian Demographic Census via SIDRA API. Automatically selects correct SIDRA table based year requested variables.

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
code: censo_populacao(   year,   variables = "total",   territorial_level = "state",   geo_code = "all",   raw = FALSE )

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: year Numeric. Census year (1970, 1980, 1991, 2000, 2010, 2022). variables Character. Type breakdown: "total": Total population "sex": sex (male/female) "age": age groups "age_sex": age groups sex "race": race/color (2000, 2010, 2022) "situation": urban/rural situation Default "total". territorial_level Character. Geographic level: "brazil", "region", "state", "municipality". Default "state". geo_code Character. IBGE code(s) specific localities. "" returns localities chosen level. Default "". raw Logical. TRUE, returns raw API output without cleaning. Default FALSE.

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: tibble population data.

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: function provides easy interface common Census queries. automatically resolves correct SIDRA table: Table 200: Historical population 1970-2010 (sex, age, situation) Table 9514: Census 2022 population sex age Table 136: Population race 2000-2010 Table 9605: Population race 2022 Table 9515: Population urban/rural 2022 flexibility, use censo_sidra_data query table custom parameters.

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
text: Data retrieved IBGE SIDRA API: https://sidra.ibge.gov.br/

title: Get Census population data — censo_populacao
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # total population by state, 2022 censo_populacao(year = 2022)  # population by sex, Brazil level censo_populacao(year = 2022, variables = "sex", territorial_level = "brazil")  # population by age and sex, 2010 censo_populacao(year = 2010, variables = "age_sex")  # population by race, 2022 censo_populacao(year = 2022, variables = "race") }

what: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
text: Queries IBGE SIDRA API retrieve Census table. flexible function, allowing full control SIDRA query parameters.

title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
code: censo_sidra_data(   table,   territorial_level = "brazil",   geo_code = "all",   year = NULL,   variable = NULL,   classifications = NULL,   raw = FALSE )

title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
text: table Numeric character. SIDRA table code. Use censo_sidra_tables censo_sidra_search find codes. territorial_level Character. Geographic level: "brazil" (N1), "region" (N2), "state" (N3), "municipality" (N6). Default "brazil". geo_code Character. IBGE code(s) specific localities. "" returns localities chosen level. Default "". year Numeric character. Year(s) query. NULL returns available periods. variable Numeric character. SIDRA variable ID(s). NULL returns variables excluding metadata. Default NULL. classifications Named list. SIDRA classification filters. Example: list("2" = "allxt") sex breakdown. NULL returns default aggregation. Default NULL. raw Logical. TRUE, returns raw API output without cleaning. Default FALSE.

title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
text: tibble queried data.

title: Get Census data from SIDRA API — censo_sidra_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # population by state from 2022 Census censo_sidra_data(   table = 9514,   territorial_level = "state",   year = 2022,   variable = 93 )  # population by race, Brazil level censo_sidra_data(   table = 9605,   territorial_level = "brazil",   year = 2022,   variable = 93,   classifications = list("86" = "allxt") ) }

what: healthbR: Access Brazilian Public Health Data — healthbR-package
title: healthbR: Access Brazilian Public Health Data — healthbR-package
text: Provides easy access Brazilian public health data multiple sources including VIGITEL (Surveillance Risk Factors Chronic Diseases Telephone Survey), PNS (National Health Survey), PNAD Continua (Continuous National Household Sample Survey), POF (Household Budget Survey food security consumption data), Censo Demografico (population denominators via SIDRA API), SIM (Mortality Information System), SINASC (Live Birth Information System), SIH (Hospital Information System), SIA (Outpatient Information System), health information systems. Data downloaded Brazilian Ministry Health IBGE repositories. Data returned tidy format following tidyverse conventions.

title: healthbR: Access Brazilian Public Health Data — healthbR-package
text: Maintainer: Sidney Bissoli sbissoli76@gmail.com (ORCID)

title: Download PNADC microdata — pnadc_data
text: Downloads returns PNADC microdata specified module year(s) IBGE FTP. Data cached locally avoid repeated downloads. arrow package installed, data cached parquet format faster subsequent reads.

code: pnadc_data(   module,   year = NULL,   vars = NULL,   as_survey = FALSE,   cache_dir = NULL,   refresh = FALSE )

title: Download PNADC microdata — pnadc_data
text: module Character. module identifier. Use pnadc_modules see available modules. Required. year Numeric vector. Year(s) download. Use NULL available years module. Default NULL. vars Character vector. Variables select. Use NULL variables. Survey design variables (UPA, Estrato, V1028) key demographic variables always included. Default NULL. as_survey Logical. TRUE, returns survey design object (requires srvyr package). Default FALSE. cache_dir Character. Directory caching downloaded files. Default uses tools::R_user_dir("healthbR", "cache"). refresh Logical. TRUE, re-download even file exists cache. Default FALSE.

text: deficiencia: Persons disabilities (2019, 2022, 2024) habitacao: Housing characteristics (2012-2019, 2022-2024) moradores: General characteristics residents (2012-2019, 2022-2024) aps: Primary health care (2022)

title: Download PNADC microdata — pnadc_data
text: proper statistical analysis complex survey design, following variables always included: UPA: Primary sampling unit Estrato: Stratum V1028: Survey weight Use as_survey = TRUE get properly weighted survey design object analysis srvyr package.

what: Get PNS tabulated data from SIDRA API — pns_sidra_data
title: Get PNS tabulated data from SIDRA API — pns_sidra_data
text: Queries IBGE SIDRA API retrieve tabulated PNS indicators. Returns pre-aggregated data (prevalences, means, proportions) confidence intervals coefficients variation.

title: Get PNS tabulated data from SIDRA API — pns_sidra_data
code: pns_sidra_data(   table,   territorial_level = "brazil",   geo_code = "all",   year = NULL,   variable = NULL,   classifications = NULL,   raw = FALSE )

title: Get PNS tabulated data from SIDRA API — pns_sidra_data
text: table Numeric character. SIDRA table code. Use pns_sidra_tables() pns_sidra_search() find codes. territorial_level Character. Geographic level: "brazil" (N1), "region" (N2), "state" (N3), "municipality" (N6). Default "brazil". geo_code Character. IBGE code(s) specific localities. "" returns localities chosen level. Default "". year Numeric. Year(s) query. NULL returns available periods. variable Numeric character. SIDRA variable ID(s). NULL returns variables excluding metadata. Default NULL. classifications Named list. SIDRA classification filters. Example: list("2" = "6794") sex = total. NULL returns default aggregation. Default NULL. raw Logical. TRUE, returns raw API output without cleaning. Default FALSE.

title: Get PNS tabulated data from SIDRA API — pns_sidra_data
text: tibble queried indicators.

title: Get PNS tabulated data from SIDRA API — pns_sidra_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # self-rated health by state, 2019 pns_sidra_data(   table = 4751,   territorial_level = "state",   year = 2019 )  # same table, Brazil-level, both years pns_sidra_data(   table = 4751,   territorial_level = "brazil",   year = c(2013, 2019) )  # hypertension data pns_sidra_data(   table = 4416,   territorial_level = "brazil" ) }

title: Download and import POF microdata — pof_data
text: year Character. POF edition (e.g., "2017-2018"). Default "2017-2018". register Character. register download. Use pof_registers() see available options. Default "morador". vars Character vector. Optional: specific variables select. NULL, returns variables register. Default NULL. cache_dir Character. Directory caching downloaded files. Default uses tools::R_user_dir("healthbR", "cache"). as_survey Logical. TRUE, returns survey design object. Requires srvyr package. Default FALSE. refresh Logical. TRUE, re-download even file exists cache. Default FALSE.

text: tibble microdata, tbl_svy as_survey = TRUE.

title: Download and import POF microdata — pof_data
text: POF (Pesquisa de Orcamentos Familiares) household survey conducted IBGE investigates household budgets, living conditions, nutritional profiles Brazilian population.

title: Download and import POF microdata — pof_data
text: POF contains several health-related modules: EBIA (Food Security Scale): Available 2017-2018, variable V6199 domicilio register Food Consumption: Detailed food consumption data consumo_alimentar register (2008-2009, 2017-2018) Health Expenses: Expenses medications, health insurance, consultations despesa_individual register Anthropometry: Weight, height, BMI morador register (2008-2009 )

title: Download and import POF microdata — pof_data

what: Download SIA Outpatient Production Microdata — sia_data
title: Download SIA Outpatient Production Microdata — sia_data
text: Downloads returns outpatient production microdata DATASUS FTP. row represents one outpatient production record. Data organized monthly – one .dbc file per type, state (UF), month.

title: Download SIA Outpatient Production Microdata — sia_data
code: sia_data(   year,   type = "PA",   month = NULL,   vars = NULL,   uf = NULL,   procedure = NULL,   diagnosis = NULL,   cache = TRUE,   cache_dir = NULL )

title: Download SIA Outpatient Production Microdata — sia_data
text: year Integer. Year(s) data. Required. type Character. File type download. Default: "PA" (outpatient production). See sia_info() 13 types. month Integer. Month(s) data (1-12). NULL (default), downloads 12 months. Example: 1 (January), 1:6 (first semester). vars Character vector. Variables keep. NULL (default), returns available variables. Use sia_variables() see available variables. uf Character. Two-letter state abbreviation(s) download. NULL (default), downloads 27 states. Example: "SP", c("SP", "RJ"). procedure Character. SIGTAP procedure code pattern(s) filter (PA_PROC_ID). Supports partial matching (prefix). NULL (default), returns procedures. Example: "0301" (consultations). diagnosis Character. CID-10 code pattern(s) filter principal diagnosis (PA_CIDPRI). Supports partial matching (prefix). NULL (default), returns diagnoses. Example: "J" (respiratory diseases). cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded data faster future access. cache_dir Character. Directory caching. Default: tools::R_user_dir("healthbR", "cache").

title: Download SIA Outpatient Production Microdata — sia_data
text: tibble outpatient production microdata. Includes columns year, month, uf_source identify source multiple years/months/states combined.

title: Download SIA Outpatient Production Microdata — sia_data
text: Data downloaded DATASUS FTP .dbc files (one per type/state/month). .dbc format decompressed internally using vendored C code blast library. external dependencies required. SIA data monthly, downloading entire year states requires 324 files (27 UFs x 12 months) per type. Use uf month limit downloads. SIA 13 file types. default "PA" (outpatient production) commonly used. Use sia_info() see types.

title: Download SIA Outpatient Production Microdata — sia_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # all outpatient production in Acre, January 2022 ac_jan <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # filter by procedure code consult <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC",                     procedure = "0301")  # filter by diagnosis (CID-10) resp <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC",                  diagnosis = "J")  # only key variables sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC",          vars = c("PA_PROC_ID", "PA_CIDPRI", "PA_SEXO",                   "PA_IDADE", "PA_VALAPR"))  # different file type (APAC Medicamentos) med <- sia_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC", type = "AM") }

what: Download SIH Hospital Admission Microdata — sih_data
title: Download SIH Hospital Admission Microdata — sih_data
text: Downloads returns hospital admission microdata DATASUS FTP. row represents one hospital admission record (AIH). Data organized monthly – one .dbc file per state (UF) per month.

title: Download SIH Hospital Admission Microdata — sih_data
code: sih_data(   year,   month = NULL,   vars = NULL,   uf = NULL,   diagnosis = NULL,   cache = TRUE,   cache_dir = NULL )

title: Download SIH Hospital Admission Microdata — sih_data
text: year Integer. Year(s) data. Required. month Integer. Month(s) data (1-12). NULL (default), downloads 12 months. Example: 1 (January), 1:6 (first semester). vars Character vector. Variables keep. NULL (default), returns available variables. Use sih_variables() see available variables. uf Character. Two-letter state abbreviation(s) download. NULL (default), downloads 27 states. Example: "SP", c("SP", "RJ"). diagnosis Character. CID-10 code pattern(s) filter principal diagnosis (DIAG_PRINC). Supports partial matching (prefix). NULL (default), returns diagnoses. Example: "I21" (acute myocardial infarction), "J" (respiratory). cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded data faster future access. cache_dir Character. Directory caching. Default: tools::R_user_dir("healthbR", "cache").

text: Data downloaded DATASUS FTP .dbc files (one per state per month). .dbc format decompressed internally using vendored C code blast library. external dependencies required. SIH data monthly, downloading entire year states requires 324 files (27 UFs x 12 months). Use uf month limit downloads.

title: Download SIH Hospital Admission Microdata — sih_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # all admissions in Acre, January 2022 ac_jan <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1, uf = "AC")  # heart attacks in Sao Paulo, first semester 2022 infarct_sp <- sih_data(year = 2022, month = 1:6, uf = "SP",                         diagnosis = "I21")  # only key variables, Rio de Janeiro, March 2022 sih_data(year = 2022, month = 3, uf = "RJ",          vars = c("DIAG_PRINC", "DT_INTER", "SEXO",                   "IDADE", "MORTE", "VAL_TOT")) }

title: Download SIM Mortality Microdata — sim_data
text: Downloads returns mortality microdata DATASUS FTP. row represents one death record (Declaracao de Obito). Data downloaded per state (UF) compressed .dbc files, decompressed internally, returned tibble.

title: Download SIM Mortality Microdata — sim_data
code: sim_data(   year,   vars = NULL,   uf = NULL,   cause = NULL,   decode_age = TRUE,   cache = TRUE,   cache_dir = NULL )

title: Download SIM Mortality Microdata — sim_data
text: year Integer. Year(s) data. Required. vars Character vector. Variables keep. NULL (default), returns available variables. Use sim_variables() see available variables. uf Character. Two-letter state abbreviation(s) download. NULL (default), downloads 27 states. Example: "SP", c("SP", "RJ"). cause Character. CID-10 code pattern(s) filter cause death (CAUSABAS). Supports partial matching (prefix). NULL (default), returns causes. Example: "I21" (infarct), "C" (neoplasms). decode_age Logical. TRUE (default), adds numeric column age_years age years decoded IDADE variable. cache Logical. TRUE (default), caches downloaded data faster future access. cache_dir Character. Directory caching. Default: tools::R_user_dir("healthbR", "cache").

title: Download SIM Mortality Microdata — sim_data
text: tibble mortality microdata. Includes columns year uf_source identify source multiple years/states combined.

title: Download SIM Mortality Microdata — sim_data
text: Data downloaded DATASUS FTP .dbc files (one per state per year). .dbc format decompressed internally using vendored C code blast library. external dependencies required. uf specified, requested state(s) downloaded, making operation much faster downloading entire country.

title: Download SIM Mortality Microdata — sim_data
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() # all deaths in Acre, 2022 ac_2022 <- sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "AC")  # deaths by infarct in Sao Paulo, 2020-2022 infarct_sp <- sim_data(year = 2020:2022, uf = "SP", cause = "I21")  # only key variables, Rio de Janeiro, 2022 sim_data(year = 2022, uf = "RJ",          vars = c("DTOBITO", "SEXO", "IDADE",                   "RACACOR", "CODMUNRES", "CAUSABAS")) }

Two-letter state abbreviation(s) download. NULL (default), downloads 27 states. Example: "SP", c("SP", "RJ"). anomaly Character. CID-10 code pattern(s) filter congenital anomaly (CODANOMAL). title: Download VIGITEL microdata — vigitel_data

title: Download VIGITEL microdata — vigitel_data
text: VIGITEL survey (Vigilância de Fatores de Risco e Proteção para Doenças Crônicas por Inquérito Telefônico) conducted annually Brazilian Ministry Health state capitals Federal District. Data includes information : Demographics (age, sex, education, race) Health behaviors (smoking, alcohol, diet, physical activity) Health conditions (hypertension, diabetes, obesity) Healthcare utilization survey uses post-stratification weights (variable pesorake) produce population estimates. Always use weights statistical inference.

title: Download VIGITEL microdata — vigitel_data

healthbR 0.6.1
text: Fixed POF dictionary parsing failure Linux/Ubuntu. utils::unzip() creates filenames invalid UTF-8 bytes non-Windows systems, caused grepl() nchar() silently fail. Dictionary file lookup now uses byte-level matching (useBytes = TRUE, nchar(type = "bytes")) renames extracted files ASCII-safe names prevent downstream encoding errors. Moved POF register validation download pof_dictionary(), invalid register names caught immediately without triggering download.

title: healthbR 0.6.1
text: Replaced \donttest{} @examplesIf interactive() across 9 modules (VIGITEL, PNS, PNADC, POF, Censo, SIM, SINASC, SIH, SIA). Examples download data now run interactive sessions, following current CRAN guidelines. Marked internal utils topic @keywords internal fix pkgdown reference index build.

title: healthbR 0.6.0
text: sia_years(), sia_info() module metadata sia_variables(), sia_dictionary() variable exploration sia_data() downloading outpatient production microdata per state (UF) sia_cache_status(), sia_clear_cache() cache management 13 file types: PA (default), BI, AD, , , AQ, AR, AB, ACF, ATD, AMP, SAD, PS. Use type parameter select. Monthly data: SIA data organized per month (one .dbc file per type/UF/month). Use month parameter select specific months. Procedure filtering SIGTAP code (procedure parameter) Diagnosis filtering CID-10 code (diagnosis parameter) Output includes year, month, uf_source columns Reuses shared DBC infrastructure (.dbc2dbf(), .read_dbc(), .datasus_download())

title: healthbR 0.2.0
text: Censo Demografico: Added module accessing population denominators IBGE SIDRA API, covering Census years 1970-2022 intercensitary estimates 2001-2021. censo_years(), censo_info() Census metadata censo_populacao() population sex, age, race, urban/rural censo_estimativa() intercensitary population estimates censo_sidra_tables(), censo_sidra_search() table discovery censo_sidra_data() querying Census SIDRA table Shared SIDRA utilities extracted utils-sidra.R (used PNS Census) Added vignette: “Population Denominators Census healthbR” POF (Pesquisa de Orçamentos Familiares): Added complete module accessing POF microdata IBGE FTP, covering editions 2002-2003, 2008-2009, 2017-2018. pof_years(), pof_info(), pof_registers() survey metadata pof_dictionary(), pof_variables() variable exploration pof_data() downloading importing microdata pof_cache_status(), pof_clear_cache() cache management Survey design support via as_survey = TRUE (requires srvyr) Health-focused data: food security (EBIA), food consumption, anthropometry, health expenses Parquet caching arrow installed Added vignette: “Analyzing Health Data POF healthbR” PNADC (PNAD Contínua): Added module health-related supplementary modules PNAD Contínua (deficiência, habitação, moradores, APS). PNS (Pesquisa Nacional de Saúde): Added module PNS microdata SIDRA tabulated data access (2013, 2019).

title: healthbR 0.2.0
text: Complete refactoring VIGITEL functions due Ministry Health website restructuring. Data now distributed single consolidated file containing years (2006-2024) instead separate files per year. vigitel_data() API changed: New format parameter choose Stata (.dta) CSV formats year parameter now defaults NULL (returns years) Removed lazy parallel parameters (replaced automatic parquet caching) Removed force_download parameter (replaced force) Removed vigitel_download() vigitel_convert_to_parquet() functions. longer needed data processing handled automatically. vigitel_variables() longer requires year parameter. Returns full data dictionary.

title: healthbR 0.2.0
text: Added 2022 2024 data (newly available Ministry Health). Available years now span 2006-2024 (19 years). vigitel_data() now supports downloading data Stata (.dta) CSV format via format parameter. Stata format recommended preserves variable labels. Automatic partitioned parquet caching: arrow package installed, data automatically cached partitioned parquet format. enables efficient reading specific years without loading entire dataset. Performance improvement: reading single year cache now extremely fast year’s partition loaded. Added haven readr Imports reading Stata CSV files. Added survey Suggests complex survey analysis support.

title: healthbR 0.2.0
